titlestmt.titleproper: All India Trade Union Congress Archives
titlestmt.subtitle: Finding aid

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid created by IISH Collection Processing Department, 2020

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: All India Trade Union Congress Archives
did.abstract: Founded on 31 October 1920 the All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) is the oldest trade union federations in India. Papers of the AITUC covering the period 1955 to 1965.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) is the oldest trade union federation in India, founded on 31 October 1920 in Bombay (now Mumbai). Among its founders were the renowned nationalist leader Lala Lajpat Rai ( 1865-1928), who became the first President of the AITUC, Joseph Baptista (1864-1930), N.M. Joshi (1879-1955) and Diwan Chaman Lall ( 1892-1973). The formation of the AITUC led to it being the designated the official representative of the Indian workers at the International Labour Organisation (ILO) from 1921 onwards.

The first trade unions had come into being from the late 19th century in India in jute, textile and clothing mills, and at the railways. Bombay (Mumbai), a textile manufacturing hub, had its first trade union in the shape of the Bombay Millhands Association, headed by Narayan Meghaji Lokhande (1848-1897). The incipient trade union movement had close links with social reform and anti-caste movements. Numerous strikes and other forms of protests by workers have been recorded throughout the 19th century. By the 20th century the unions extended their work to other sectors including municipal workers, the printing press, engineering goods factories, etc. The period from 1900 to 1920 also witnessed hundreds of strikes, mass meetings and processions. During these years trade unionists closed ranks with those leading the freedom struggle against colonial rulers. The unions had gone on strike in 1908 opposing the arrest of the popular freedom struggle leader Bal Gangadhar Tilak, who later on took the initiative for hosting the all-India congregation of unions to form a national centre.

Stalwarts of Indian freedom struggle like Jawahar Lal Nehru (1889-1964), Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose (1897-1945), V.V. Giri (1894-1980) also chaired sessions of the AITUC. At the beginning the AITUC had 64 affiliated unions with 140,000 members. It grew to become the largest trade union confederation in India by 1947. Well known trade unionists of the time attended sessions of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) and N.M. Joshi was a long standing member of the governing body of the ILO representing the workers.

In the late 1920s the AITUC became more radical, partly under influence of the emerging communist movement. A split followed in 1929, and the Indian Trade Union Federation (ITUF) led by former AITUC president V.V. Giri was founded. AITUC and ITUF merged again in 1939, and since then the AITUC continued playing its role as “vanguard of the working class”. The AITUC also played an important role in the struggle for independence, and was very influential in the foundation of World Federation of Trade Unions (WFTU), 1945. The AITUC had a close association with the Communist Party of India (established 1925), but was never formally affiliated to it. The principle followed throughout from its foundation conference was “Free from Governments, free from Managements & Free from Political Parties”. Its membership has been given as 14.2 million in 2013, making it the third largest trade union confederation in India. The AITUC has its headquarters in New Delhi.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The collection presented here consists mainly of the documents of the AITUC for the period 1928-1970 that were included in one of the major digitization projects of trade union documents of "The Archives of Indian Labour", set up in 1998 as a collaborative initiative of the V.V.Giri National Labour Institute (VVGNLI) and the Association of Indian Labour Historians (AILH). In a project initiated by the Center for Modern Indian Studies (CeMIS, Göttingen, Germany) and confirmed through a memorandum of understanding (MOU) between AITUC, AILH, CeMIS and the International Institute of Social History (IISH), the extant digital collection is being standardized, and the metadata updated and published online. Subsequently the project aims to digitize and make available to the public other material and documents with the AITUC. Under the MOU mentioned above, the IISH provides long-term storage of a copy of the digital files and access to the collection through its catalog and platforms.
The project has received financial support from the "International Center for Advanced Studies: Metamorphoses of the Political (ICAS: MP)" and from the Max Weber Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition
acqinfo.p: A copy of the digital files is preserved in the digital repository of the IISH

scopecontent.head: Content
scopecontent.p: This part of the archives contains correspondence, minutes, reports, resolutions and other documents related to the Congresses, General Council, Working Committee and the Secretariat of the AITUC from the period 1955-1965.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: List made by the ICAS:MP project team, 2018-2020, based on lists made within the Archives of Indian Labour project (1998 - onwards).

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Only digitized documents are available for use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: All India Trade Union Congress Archives, inventory number ..., International Institute of Social History, Amsterdam

originalsloc.head: Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: Originals held in the V.V. Giri National Labour Institute (VVGNLI, Noida, India)

altformavail.head: Alternative Form
altformavail.p: Documents digitized as part of the digitisation project "The Archives of Indian Labour", 1998-2020

scopecontent.p: Correspondence of AITUC centre with various affilitated trade unions related to the formation of the reception committee for and other issues related to the 27th session of AITUC in December 1965 at Indore; Letters to and from faternal unions regarding their presence in the conference; Correspondence of letters regarding the postponement of the conference and the difference of opinion with the central leadership.

scopecontent.p: Documents and Resolutions of AITUC Conference of 1957: Resolutions paased in the conference on Social Security; Wages and Bonus, Peace and the banning of Weapons of Mass Destruction; Goa Liberation, Colonialism, Food Crisis, Tripartite Agreement and code of discipline, Workers' Unity, Supreme Court and tthe Amendment of the constitution, Labour laws, Samyukta Maharashtra and Maha Gujrat agitations. Resoluion on various unions like Oil Mill Workers' Union, Hotel Workers' Union, Plantation, Mine, Textile and Mica workers' demands and recent agitations.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains speeches and writings of S.A. Dange, Indrajit Gupta, Bhpesh Gupta and other trade unionist of AITUC on workers' issues, Industrial employment amendment bill, companies amendment bill general budget, tripartite meeting, five years' plan and economic growth. Notes on the 3rd National Conference for Afro-Asian solidarity, speeches by foreign degniteries and a note on economic cooperation between India and Yugoslavia by Yugoslavian Embassy. Report on the 17th session of ECAF statement by K.B. Panikker and a press note on the demonstration in Delhi following the Murder of Patrice Lumumba.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains resolutions passed at the 9th conference of the West Bengal Unit of the CPI. Letter dealing with the west-German assistance in the Rourkela plant.

scopecontent.p: Copy of the speech of S.A. Dange on Indo-China dispute given in Bihar; Documents related to the parliamentry group of the CPI; Correspondence between S.A. Dange and various workers' unions, state and district committees of CPI; Correspondence between S.A. Dange and various other communist leaders like Sajjad Zaheer, E.M.S. Namboodaripad, Muzaffar Ahmad, Bhupesh Gupta, Abdus Sattar, P.C.. Joshi, Ajoy Ghosh, Jyoti Basu and others; Circular for CPI state committees related to the railway workers' movement; Brief report on the preparation for Mansoon session, 1959; Strike action in plantation sector; Press statements issued by the CPI; Statement issued by the Manipur state executive committee of CPI; CPI note on the Pak-US pact; Documents, bills, criculars and reports related to the Kerala following the formation of state government by the CPI; UP state CPI pamphlet on food crisis and price rise in the state.
